title: Intelligence Analyst/Cryptologic Technician Second Class - CTR2(SW)
description: National Security Operations Center Collections Officer, NSA Fort Meade (2006-2008) Monitored SIGINT collection, forwarding and processing posture of the United States Cryptologic System and recommended collection resource changes in response to time-sensitive intelligence interests and requirements. Conducted DNR activities in support of missions relating to terrorism. Maintained near 100% accuracy on all reports and activities completed. Overseas Operation Center (2004-2006) Maintained overall situational awareness as the Situational Awareness Cell Senior Operator; compiling all-source information on local Asia-Pacific and World-Wide events; provided information to Watch Commanders and Officers. Provided analysis to watch commanders, pulling data from multiple sources, classified and unclassified, to give an overall posture of the target arena. Obtained 100% accuracy of reporting working with Short Duration Signals analysis and reporting as CERCIS operator. Supervised and conducted the training for over fifteen multi-service personnel. U.S. Naval Vessel (2000-2004) Conducted tactical Cryptologic operations afloat as SSEE Operator; including own-force monitoring, Indications and Warning, Exploitation Operations, Maritime Interdiction Operations and All-Source Analysis. Supervised and conducted training for five operators on the Global Combat Support System (Maritime) suite, related equipment and duties. Conducted two Western Pacific patrols to the Middle East in support of Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom. Stood Helm and Lee Helm watches, adjusting ship's speed and course in accordance with the orders of the Officer Of the Deck.

title: Foreign Affairs Specialist
description: Served as the first Foreign Area Noncommissioned Officer (FANCO) in the Army. As a FANCO in U.S. Army Europe I served as the primary representative to multinational partner nation Senior Noncommissioned Officer leadership and the liaison for the Land Forces Command Sergeants Major of 51 partner nations throughout the U.S. Army Europe footprint. Prepared informational read-ahead material and talking points for senior leader visits to partner nations, contributed to assessments of countries based upon U.S. European Command Country Cooperation Plans, and facilitated military to military engagements between countries. Also served as the FANCO program manager ensuring the growth and expansion of the program, the training and development of FANCOs, and the socialization of this new program through the authoring of white papers and articles pertaining to it. Conducted senior leader engagement visits to more than 23 countries alongside senior U.S. Army Europe leadership. These security cooperation efforts helped support the over 1,000 theater security cooperation events in more than 40 countries each year that lead directly to support for multinational contingency operations around the world, strengthening regional partnerships, and enhancing global security.

Upon return from Iraq served in a newly developed Multifunctional Team (MFT) program as the team leader. title: Reconnaissance Specialist (Cavalry Scout)
description: The cavalry scout is responsible for being the eyes and ears of the commander during battle. They engage the enemy in the field, track and report their activity and direct the employment of weapon systems to their locations. During this time I served as a Bradley Fighting Vehicle crew member for two different Armored Reconnaissance Squadrons with worldwide contingency missions. I was responsible for four personnel and their families in areas such as training, professional development and their general health and welfare. I was also responsible for one Bradley Fighting Vehicle and all assigned equipment worth in excess of 1.5 million dollars. I served a the maintenance supervisor for my platoon during this time ensuring all operator level maintenance was completely on all vehicles assigned to the platoon on a weekly basis. I deployed to Baghdad for the first time in 2003 as a gunner on a Bradley Fighting Vehicle conducting well over 40 real-world combat missions prior to being severely wounded and evacuated out of theater.

description: Member of a 40 personnel Military in Transition Team (MiTT) for a combat deployment to Iraq, and educated Iraqi security and intelligence personnel in Human Intelligence (HUMINT) operations, collection, map reading, symbology, and tactical questioning. Author and editor--had unique ability to handle the friction, personalities and distractions of a complex, high-priority project and get things done right and on-time.

education.name: University of New Hampshire -- Peter T. Paul College of Business and Economics

title: Flight Commander, Chief of Electronic Warfare, Chief of Weapons and Tactics
description: Plans, manages and executes operational test and evaluation of F-111 aircraft systems and weapons. Developed tactics and employment concepts for test, training and weapons. Test project officer for ALR-62I radar warning receiver, Pave Tack operational flight program, GBU-24 A/B, HAVE NAP data-linked missile (only WSO to employ this Israeli-built missile from an F-111), AGM-65G Maverick missile, F-111D operational flight program, and F-111F Pacer Strike modification ($155M modification). Provided sound, detailed and accurate test plans--exceeded test milestone always ahead of schedule while saving significant test funds. Completely re-wrote technical orders and checklists, and achieved direct hits on targets for all new weapons. During Operation Desert Storm, tested night, low level Pave Tack tactics to support upcoming operations and played a critical role in developing, testing and fielding the GBU-28 hard target penetrating weapon. Worked in Checkmate as targeting officer in Operation Desert Storm. Led the Iraqi Task Force hard penetration efforts and was responsible for integrating 1,300+ USN, USMC and USAF fighter aircraft missions into the Air Tasking Order. As a joint-service war planning expert, developed air options for CENTCOM’s Desert Storm campaign. Personally recognized by the SECAF for his development of the “Battle of the Shelters” option for the CINC’s air campaign.

title: F-111F Instructor WSO; Squadron EWO; Wing Weapons Officer
description: Early upgrade to Instructor. 3x Wing Top Gun winner. Repeatedly lauded as Best WSO in the squadron--a self-starter with outstanding initiative. Trained and instructed 120 aircrews on tactics, electronic warfare, weapons employment--specifically precision guided munitions, nuclear certification and NATO tasked conventional plans/missions. Distinguished Graduate for outstanding performance in the highest level tactical flying program in the Air Force--Fighter Weapons School. As the Wing Weapons Officer, developed a program to manage the wing's live and training ordnance, received an 'Excellent' rating by the USAFE inspection team. In addition, directed the annual training employment of 120 PGMs valued at $1.5M. Unflappable management of academic and combat weapon delivery programs resulted in the highest number of aircrews qualified in PGM deliveries in 3 years. Recognized for superior efforts as a tactics planner and aircrew member for Operation Eldorado Canyon.
